name: AI NEXTCon Developers Conference 2019 - San Francisco
description:
4-days, 50+ tech lead speakers, 60+ tech talks, hands-on workshop/code labs, immersive AI trainings. presented by engineering teams from Microsoft Amazon Uber Airbnb Pinterest Google Facebook Twitter Linkedin, Nvidia, Intel, etc...

If you are a developer looking to hone your skills, a tech lead and manager to learn latest AI tech that apply to your engineering teams to innovate products and services, or someone who just wants to learn more about the AI industry that's re-shaping the tech world, the AI NEXTCon is right for you.

Now it's 9th edition, AI NEXTCon is specially geared to developers, data scientists to share, learn, and practice AI technology and how applying AI to innovate products and services, solve engineering problems. The conference features a blend of inspirational keynotes, deep dive tech talks, hands-on workshops, tools/framework live demo, networking opportunity with like minded developers.

Official Website:
http://aisf19.xnextcon.com

Date:
*Main Conference: 10/8~9, 2019
*Hands-on Workshop: 10/10~11, 2019
*Deep Learning Training: 10/10~11, 2019

Topics/Tracks:
*Computer Vision
*NLP
*Machine Learning and Production lifecycle
*Deep Learning and tools
*Data Science & Analytics

more details on the website: http://aisf19.xnextcon.com

name: (paid) Online live AI course: Deep learning for developers
description:
For high demand, we schedule the new session for this course again in October. This course is online live course. You can listen, watch, interact, Q&A with instructors from anywhere around the world. Miss the live session due to time zone or conflict? you can learn session replay at any time afterwards.

course start date/time: 10/15 10am PT (US pacific time, check your local time zone).
* 16 hours, 8 sessions, 10 live lectures, 12 hands-on code labs.
* adding more coding exercises and projects.

Registration:
https://learn.xnextcon.com/course/coursedetails/C19101510

Details:
learn deep learning by building deep learning models and projects.
The course takes unique project focused approach to teach you deep learning by building deep learning models. The instructor will walk you through a series of curated projects, and explain the key concepts as they arise. Students will learn the theory and how these models work under the hood while writing code, and building neural networks.

The course balances learning theory, working on projects, and also hearing from guest speakers who are industry practitioners in the field.

*Identify and frame problems that can be solved by deep learning
*Choose the right techniques to the problems
*Understand key deep learning concepts and how deep learning models work
*Build deep neural nets for classification on images as well as structured data using the Keras.
*Build convolutional neural networks for image classification and segmentation using the Keras.

Online AI tech talks, courses, bootcamps : https://learn.xnextcon.com

name: Google hands-on workshop on Machine Learning and NLP
description:
** we are looking for venue for this event.
* ~50 attendees, workshop style (with desk/chairs for code labs)
* with standard projection system and wifi (for code labs)
* we can update the date/time to the venue availability (10am-4pm OR 4pm-9pm)
Let me know if your company can sponsor the venue.
The event is ~5 hours (10am-4pm or 4pm-9pm), we can be flexible on the date.
---------------------
This hands-on workshop is for developers of all skill level to come together to learn machine learning on NLP with Tensorflow.

Get Free official Google training. Together we'll work through several Machine learning labs. You will get hands-on experience with the Machine Learning and Tensorflow. The event features a blend of tech talks, code labs, discussions, demos and networking.

After our live session, you will have free access to more labs you can finish at home. Complete all labs in the quest and earn a Google-hosted badge for your online profile, and additional 30 days access to the training platform to compete any labs you want.

Agenda:
9:30am: Checkin
10:00am: welcome and intro
10:05am: Intro on Machine learning and Tensorflow
10:30am: code lab 1
11:30am: code lab 2
12:00pm: lunch/break
1:00pm: code lab 3
2:00pm: code lab 4
3:00pm: code lab 5
4:00pm: Wrap up and close

Bring a laptop and charger (PC, Mac or Chromebook)! The labs will run on all of the latest versions of the popular browsers. For the best experience, make sure your laptop has Firefox or Chrome installed. Don’t forget your charger.

name: SQL Server on Linux
description:
Details
1st PRESENTATION -Rattling Tech Talks
Azure Blob storage
Blob storage is a feature in Microsoft Azure that lets developers store unstructured data in Microsoft's cloud platform. This data can be accessed from anywhere in the world.In this presentation we will see how to do SQL Native backups to Azure Blob storage.

By
Senthuran Subramaniam. Sen has Overall 10 years experience in the I.T field with 4 years as SQL Server developer. He has great expertise in Database Development and Administration.

MAIN PRESENTATION
SQL Server on Linux

In this presentation we will see below :-

Installing SQL Server on RedHat Linux
A brief demonstration of installing SQL Server on Linux
Navigating Linux SQL Server on Linux
How to Log onto Linux
Changing your password
Using ‘sudo’
Basic Linux Commands
Information Gathering
Troubleshooting

BY
MAIN PRESENTER

Jeanne has over 15 years of experience in the Information Technology field starting out as an Analyst Programmer and then becoming a database administrator. I have worked in variety of fields ranging from Higher education, healthcare, energy and telecommunications. As a DBA, I have worked on various database platforms ranging from Oracle, MySQL, Postgres and SQL Server to name a few. I am familiar working in both Windows and Linux operating systems and with the release of SQL Server 2017 on Linux I was excited to try it. I will be sharing with you commands and shortcuts on how to install and navigate through Linux.

------------------------------------------------------------
5:30 Pizza and networking
6:00 Meeting starts, introductions, announcements (punctual start)
6:15 First Presentation (TBD)
6:45 Main Presentation(Demystify SQL Server Performance)
8:00 Wrap-up, Q/A, address technical issue of the group
8:15 Meeting ends

Questions? Send an email to [masked].
Connect with us online:
Website: BoulderSql.org

name: Demystify SQL Server Performance
description:
Details
1st PRESENTATION -Rattling Tech Talks on Topics. We will have one member present.

MAIN PRESENTATION
Demystify SQL Server Performance

A key component of overall application performance tuning is query tuning. Writing queries in an efficient manner, and making sure they execute in the most optimal way possible, is always a challenge. This presentation will show few scenarios where some of the SQL features negatively affects performance, discuss and see how these problems can be mitigated and thereby improving performance.

BY
MAIN PRESENTER

Anup Gopinathan, is a Sr SQL Server database consultant at Datavail. He has worked with many customers over past 10 years, helping them with performance tuning, writing TSQL codes, powershell scripting and automations, high availability and disaster recovery solution, migration to cloud and developing solutions. He is a SQL Server MCITP and AWS certified Solution Architect Professional. He has also presented at PASS Summit and likes to share his new findings and knowledge via his blog post: https://www.datavail.com/author/anup-gopinathan/

Anup lives north of Denver so he loves to hike, take photographs, read books, cook. He is also a sport enthusiast and enjoys cricket, volley ball, badminton, American football.

------------------------------------------------------------

name: Boulder Blockchain
description:
Come nerd out about blockchain technology and cryptocurrency with other Boulder-based blockchain enthusiasts. After the scheduled meetup we move the conversation to a nearby bar.

New to Blockchain/Cryptocurrencies? Watch these videos before the meetup:
• 2.5 minute summary of blockchain technology (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6WG7D47tGb0)
• 5.5 minute summary of how the bitcoin blockchain works (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t5JGQXCTe3c)

A huge thanks to Peregrine for hosting our meetup!

Can't make the meetup? Join us on Slack (http://www.slackpass.io/coloradoblockchain), where the conversation is always active!
how_to_find_us: Peregrine is located in the Riverside building. Use the main entrance on Broadway. Free 1.5 hour parking across Broadway and at the library.

name: Bitcoin Get-Together
description:
Join us for some food and drinks while we discuss the current state of Bitcoin. There will be good conversation with good people from our local community. Hope to see you there!

Please bring your fiat or Satoshis to settle the tab on this evening. The venue won't allow a group check to be split more than five ways. Thank you!

name: Weekly FREE Coworking day for Blockchain and Open Source
description:
We are please to invite you to the community of developers, designers, creatives, dreamers, BUIDLers, and business leaders here at Enterprise every Thursday for FREE coworking!

This is open to anyone interested in anything Blockchain and/or Open Source. Come to work, come to meet other amazing people, come to network, and maybe get a job with a local company.

Just let the front desk know you are here for "the blockchain free day" and they will hook you up with a badge! Most of us work outside the Opolis office, ask the front desk folks to direct you.

Love it here at Enterprise? We know we do. Ask the front desk about membership options to join us every day and be sure to let them know Denver Blockchain sent you!

More on enterprise: https://enterprisecoworking.com/

In the mean time, please join the community online to get more connected:
http://launchpass.com/coloradoblockchain

We have coffee, tea, beer, and (sometimes) snacks available to you while you are here.

Can't wait to see you!
how_to_find_us: Ask the front desk to point you to the Opolis office - on the first floor members area. Feel free to call Dan 7207727755 if you want to get introduced to the community!

name: Blockchain and Cryptocurrency Community Gathering
description:
This weekly meetup is a community driven gathering on all things Crypto, Blockchain, and Distributed Ledger Technologies. We enjoy diving deep and conversing the most important aspects of these new technologies. Active participation is highly encouraged! Come prepared with any questions or topics you want to dive into. Better yet - come with something to speak about or teach everyone!

Among us, there is no such thing as a stupid question or topic. Everyone at any level of knowledge is welcome!

Some running topics include:

Discussion of news highlights from the week
Understanding the fundamentals: how it all works and why
Deep dives into software architecture and structure
Demos of basic development of blockchains and Dapps
Getting started with a crypto exchange
Different wallet types and hands-on demos of use
Security and privacy in crypto
What to look for in evaluating potential investments
Trading and Technical Analysis (TA)
Regulatory, Tax, and Legal best-practices
Legislative news and how to get involved

***Refreshments are typically available! And it is more than alright to bring dinner in! Maybe event extra to share with the group :)
how_to_find_us: There will be a sign at the main entrance to point you in the right direction. Usually downstairs in the "classroom".

name: Magic Money :: The BITCOIN Revolution Film Screening
description:
Join us at Alternation Brewing Company in Denver for a screening of Magic Money: The Bitcoin Revolution

Synopsis ::

"With the advent of Bitcoin, the world's premier digital currency, for the first time in history money is no longer controlled by banks or governments, but by the people who use it.

But where did this currency come from? How does it work? And is it truly the way forward, or just a flash in the pan?

Magic Money answers these questions and more as it explores the mysterious origins of Bitcoin, its role in society, and how it could shape the future of our world."

https://www.magicmoneyfilm.com

** Food will be available from a local vegan food truck **

><><><><><><><><><><><><

Want to access hidden knowledge?

THE A.R.K. DRIVE consists of over 1,800 video files, almost 8,000 digital books, and over 20,000 audio files. These files will always be available to you for offline browsing, playback and study, with no internet connection required to access any of the data on the drive.

Bring a 1TB external hard drive (3.0) to receive this data for free! Information on the HD will include videos, articles, etc. about Natural Law, Anarchy, the Federal Reserve System, and so much more.

Find out more at:

https://www.whatonearthishappening.com/ark

*** You will not need to ship a hard drive to Mark Passio as we will have the files available at the screening ***

AND! We will be giving away a few thumb drives (not 1TB) and raffling off one 1TB external hard drive that holds data originating from The A.R.K. Drive. Data will feature information regarding the Federal Reserve and Cryptocurrencies.
how_to_find_us: In the back on the patio

name: #AdoptionGravy: WAX.io and Lynx Chain
description:
Operation #adoptiongravy

We are in a quandary. DAPP developers are hesitant due to lingering governance issues preventing a stable enterprise worthy environment and the masses haven't migrated from data pirate platforms due to the UXUI issues that persist on modern chains.

Are there projects working on these issues? What are some of the solutions?

Come out as we look into WAX.io and Lynx Chain to explore how they are tackling them to build momentum aboard the Adoption Gravy Train.

NOTE: We might have some changes to this meetup so stay tuned for details.

name: Hedera Hashgraph Happy Hour and H-Bars, New Meetup Location
description:
New Location for Meetup.

Carbon Bar and Cafe
2200 California St
Denver, Co 80205
(720)[masked]

We're excited to announce that Hedera's community testing program is now live. Join us for this Meetup to find out how you can earn up to 250 Hbars by participating in the test program. Please bring your cell phone, driver’s license, and laptop to complete the onboarding process to the Hedera network.

At this meetup, Hedera will be focused on the Hedera developer experience. We will be presenting on the Hedera Community Testing Program, which allows users to earn Hbars by performing micropayments, testing the Hedera browser extension and using the example media website DailyTimestamp.com.

During happy hour over pizza and beer, we will get on to the test net and earning Hbars. Food will be provided by Hedera, including one free beer per person.

No matter your interest or participation level, whether you are an investor, a business owner, a developer, or you just want to know more about the technology, this is your place to be.

Hedera Portal site - https://portal.hedera.com/register

FAQ Website - https://help.hedera.com/hc/en-us/sections/360000176497-Hedera-Mainnet-Community-Testing-Program
how_to_find_us: Ask for Hedera Hashgraph Meetup

name: Hadoop Rising - The evolving ecosystem
description:
I am happy to announce that Galvanize will be hosting our meetup once again at the Walnut St. location in Boulder. As an organizer it will be fun to present on the evolution of Hadoop, and how Kubernetes is pushing the ecosystem into modern deployments. Please come out and see my demo on deploying Spark on Kubernetes.

Agenda
6:00 – 6:45 - Socialize over food and drinks
6:45 – 7:00 - Welcome, opening remarks and announcements
7:00 – 8:30 – Presentation by David Grier - Hadoop Rising
8:30 - 9:00 - Networking

Hadoop Rising
The evolution of Hadoop - a look at where the ecosystem is changing to align with support of modern infrastructure and application scheduling. Plus, a look at how industry leaders are taking advantage of this new tech.

Kubernetes is changing how we can provide solid infrastructures for rapid and even automated deployments, as well as application scheduling. We will take a look at Spark on Kubernetes as well as a deployment demo on a IaaS.

Speaker Bio:
David Grier - BigData Engineering at Rackspace/ObjectRocket. Providing devops deployments, product engineering support and architecture solutions.

Thank you to Rackspace who will be providing food and drink.

name: Meet for Coffee to talk DevOps
description:
This meetup is very informal - it is a show up, have a coffee and chat about work kind of thing.

Basically, it's all about making your systems and services more reliable, so typical topics might be configuration management, deployment, monitoring or the quirks of deploying on AWS/Google Compute Engine/Azure or on-premise hardware, whether in a server room or a data center, but the discussion topics are really up to whoever is there.

I'm the tall guy with a goatee and a light brown leather backpack. If other people haven't shown up yet I'll have my laptop out and the lid is encrusted with tech stickers. I'm fairly hard to miss.

Don't feel you have to stay for the whole 90 minutes - show up when you can, get your caffeine, stay as long as you want, then go.
how_to_find_us: I've got a tan leather backpack, am usually wearing a geeky t shirt, and my laptop lid is covered in nerdy stickers that any ops or SRE type will recognize.

name: Agile Denver Kanban CoP
description:
Agile Denver Kanban CoP: is a community of practice for practitioners interested in sharing and learning with others about applying lean thinking, lean management (leadership), and an agile mindset, along with pull, flow, kanban, and system thinking concepts to assist with catalyzing and effectively managing change to improve their business workflow processes, and to predictably forecast and answer the question “When will it be done?” It is one of several "special interest groups" (SIGs) of the broader Agile Denver user group and is also associated with the global Lean & Kanban University, and global Lean and Kanban community.

Hi All,

Hello everyone,

Our next Agile Denver Kanban CoP meetup will be on Thursday (10/10), from 6:00-8:00 pm. The first hour of our CoP meetup consists of a Deep-dive discussion. One or more CoP core members facilitate this discussion on a specific topic, related to applying and using lean, flow, pull, or kanban concepts, and selected by them from a list of candidate topics (options) that the CoP maintains. Please note the Deep-dive discussions are not limited to being introductions to lean, flow, pull, or kanban concepts. However, they are open to all who want to attend regardless of their experience level.

After a short break, the second hour of our CoP meetup typically consists of a "Lean Coffee" format, where everyone attending puts forth questions, issues, topics, etc. to be considered related to applying and using lean, flow, pull, or kanban concepts, and these can be at any experience level. If you're not familiar with Lean Coffee, a quick Google search can provide a number of brief overviews. These Lean Coffees are themselves a great way to help identify potential future Deep-dive topics of interest.

If any of that sounds interesting to you, we hope you'll join us!

Take care,

Frank
www.vissinc.com

Additional Location Info:
Plenty of visitor parking directly in front of the building along Greenwood Plaza Blvd.

Dan Wyks or Jonathan Ray from DHI will need to badge us into the building, and up to the 4th floor, and into our suite.

After 6:00 pm access is limited and, so please arrive promptly. After 6:05 we'll likely not have anyone posted at the door.

NOTE: seating is limited, so please RSVP early, and also please update your RSVP ASAP if your plans change and you know you'll not be attending. We want to provide accurate information and not turn away anyone on the waiting list unnecessarily.

name: Embracing Endless Change in our Products, Priorities, People & Process
description:
NOTE: This Meetup will be at the Galvanize - Platte location!

Change is inevitable. Colleen will discuss the four facets of change that are constantly affecting us: changing products, changing priorities, changing people and changing process . We will look at where these changes comes from, the impacts they have on us and explore concrete practices we can use to get better at responding to them. You will leave with a new attitude on the churn that takes place around us everyday. Learn to acknowledge the benefits that constant change has so you can truly welcome it into your team, your practices, and your life.

ABOUT COLLEEN:
Colleen is the CEO and cofounder of ScatterSpoke, a space for more effective team retrospectives. In her coaching, she applies a systems thinking approach to aligning agile methodologies across the enterprise and works with clients to apply the right cultural and context-driven practices to create sustainable agility. She is an expert in the Kanban method of software delivery and advocates for Lean practices of customer-centered product discovery. She has served as a board member for Agile Denver and as a chair for 2016 & 2017 Mile High Agile Conferences. She is an active board member for the Agile Uprising.

name: Thing Three - The Power of Personal Agility & Peer Coaching
description:
Personal agility can make a huge difference in reaching your work and personal goals. Add peer coaching to the mix, and you’ll be unstoppable! But how do you get started and make it stick? We’d love to share our informal personal agility & peer coaching method that combines personal responsibility and goal setting in a way that is guaranteed to be successful. We call it “Thing Three.” In this interactive session, we will teach you the basic format we follow and why it works. We will also demonstrate how it has helped even the busiest colleagues stay accountable consistently, over the years, and continue to reach every goal they set. You’ll get to exercise these skills too and immediately see the value of peer coaching!

Come mingle, meet like minds over some food and drinks and then settle in to learn a few new things to take back to your teams

Schedule:
6:00 - 6:30 Enjoy food and drinks while mingling
6:30 - 6:45 Announcements/ logistics
6:45 - 8:00 Presentation and then clean up

Bios:
Lieschen Gargano - Scrum Master @ Scaled Agile Inc.
I am a scrum master and agile coach with a background in conflict resolution and change management. I am currently applying my skills coaching non-development teams on business agility practices. In my spare time I love exploring the mountains near my Boulder CO home with my family.

William Kammersell - Curriculum Product Manager @ Scaled Agile Inc.
I am a Product Manager who loves to help teams and individuals build the best products they can. I’ve worked with agile teams for over 10 years as a developer, scrum master, agile coach, and product manager. But what excites me the most is applying the agile principles and techniques that help us succeed as teams to my personal life.

name: DDD - Lean Coffee
description:
Lean Coffee facilitated by Josh Maletz

"Lean Coffee is a structured, but agenda-less meeting. Participants gather, build an agenda, and begin talking. Conversations are directed and productive because the agenda for the meeting was democratically generated." - http://leancoffee.org/

Join us for an evening discussion on all topics that you are interested in. We will build out an agenda on whatever it is our participants would like to discuss. Have a design issue troubling you at work? Always wanted to talk about consistency boundaries to help design better aggregates? Concerned about your implementation of an event store and want to run it by some fellow practitioners? Here is your chance to share your troubles, questions, successes, and experience in general with the community.

Schedule

- 6:30 PM: Food & drink (including alcohol) provided and conversation
- 7:00 PM: Announcements
- 7:05 PM: Main Session

About the Facilitator

Josh Maletz is the co-organizer of DDD Denver.

name: Mile High Hacks Hackathon
description:
***In order to attend you must RSVP here: https://events.eventzilla.net/e/mile-high-hacks-2138759704

HEY DENVER! LET'S MAKE SOME STUFF!

Are you a coder looking to get your name out there?

Or are you a dev team leads who is looking for potential hires?

Maybe you're a designer who just loves making cool stuff with new people?

You're in luck! Mile High Hacks wants all of you to come to spend 24 hours building some sick new tech.

Come pitch your idea (or just join a team)
Spend a whole day making a completely fleshed out idea (or a proof of concept)
Show it off in front of an excited crowd (or watch someone else on your team demo)
PARTY (or PAAARTAAYYY!)

Hang out with AWS, World Wide Technologies, Denver Indie Hackers, Denver React Meetup, Hotel Engine, and Code for Denver. Have free food and drinks. Plus your team might even win a cash prize!

Currently, the prize total is at $1500!

Theme?

This event is all about Denver and the awesome people who live here: Kind of a “Neighborhood Hack”. Let’s connect people together using technology. Maybe people make a rideshare app to help people find a way up to the slopes; Maybe a food truck finder; Maybe a way to rent out your parking spot. We’re looking for ideas that bring Denverites together and help each other out!

Who's this for?

Our goal is to make this as fun as possible for developers/designers, and one of the consistent pieces of feedback we got from people was that at other events sometimes there are just a bunch of recent bootcamp grads and recruiters. Our goal is to make sure that doesn’t happen. We’re shooting for this as the average team at the hackathon

1-2 Junior Devs

1-3 Mid/Senior Devs

1 Designer

To that end, we stacked the deck with fun/experienced devs before we opened this up to the public. We are also making sure that we check in with experience levels as people sign up so that the ratios don’t lean too junior. We hope this makes it so people can make some really fun projects!

What’s the Schedule?

One of the other big pieces of feedback we got was that an all-weekend hackathon was simply not feasible for people. Work your butt off all weekend, and then got back to work on Monday. No fun. So… we’re not going to do that! We’re doing a 24-hour blitz hack.

Friday, Oct 25th - Pitch night partaaaay! (Participants only)

6 pm - Hangout time before official events.

7 pm - People pitch ideas. Everyone cheers and drink beers!

8 pm - People break into teams, and designate a team leader

After pm -> HANG OUT! (Maybe some crazy people start coding right away?!?!?!)

Saturday Oct 26th - Build, Show, and Victory!

7 am - Doors open if people want to come in early, stake out a spot and have some coffee, and bagels and stuff.

8 am - Team leaders from every team are at the space by this time to make sure they know what’s up. Connect with volunteer staff

9 am - Ideally all participants are present and making stuff from this point onward we’ll do ourly shout-out stand-ups where every team says 1 sentence about what they’ve done.

Noon - Lunch is provided! Beer begins!

6 pm - Dinner is provided! Beer Continues!

6:30 pm - We connect with every team to make sure their demo can hook into the display system and go over what order they’ll be in.

8 pm - (Open to the public) Everyone has a quick demo of their thing (It definitely won’t be a broken, hack-y mess… definitely!). Then our judges will pick a winner, and they get a prize. HOORAY!

After pm - HANG OUT! (Maybe some crazy people KEEP CODING?!?!?)

What organizations are helping make this happen?

World Wide Technology
Galvanize
Hotel Engine
Denver Indie Hackers
AWS
Denver React Meetup
Code for Denver
… and maybe yours!

If you would like to get your company/group involved contact Clayton Weller at [masked]

name: Flutter for Web and Other News in the Flutter and Dart Ecosystem
description:
You might know Flutter as Google's UI toolkit for building cross-platform mobile apps. But it's also coming to the web. In fact, it's already here. Google just announced that the developer preview for Flutter for Web is now just a part of Flutter. Which means technically Flutter should be ready for production use on the web. It's still early days though. Is it really ready for prime time? In this talk we'll discuss the good and the not so good of using Flutter for your website. We'll also discuss the progress Flutter and Dart have made in general throughout the year.

name: Intro to Cortex: Long-Term Prometheus Store+Adopting Istio, One YAML at a Time
description:
Please join us for our next meet-up in October! We'll be covering two presentations – "Intro to Cortex: A Horizontally Scalable Long-Term Store for Prometheus" with Chris Marchbanks from Splunk + "Adopting Istio, One YAML at a Time " with Megan O'Keefe from Google.

---

AGENDA

[06:30 - 07:00 PM] Dinner/Drinks (provided by Aspen Mesh) + Beer (Google)

[07:00 - 07:30 PM] Intro to Cortex: A Horizontally Scalable Long-Term Store for Prometheus with Chris Marchbanks from Splunk

Cortex allows users to deploy a horizontally scalable, centralised, and globally aggregated view of all their Prometheus instances, storing data indefinitely. This talk will discuss what problems Cortex solves, Cortex's architecture, and how to get started. Cortex is a CNCF Sandbox project.

BIO: Chris is a Software Engineer at Splunk where he delivers observability for teams working on multiple internal Kubernetes clusters. He is a maintainer of Prometheus and Cortex, and is passionate about all things observability. Outside of work, Chris enjoys skiing uphill in the mountains near Boulder.

[07:30 - 08:00 PM] Adopting Istio, One YAML at a Time with Megan O'Keefe from Google

Microservices are hard: more services, more network hops, more programming languages. Kubernetes can help you lifecycle and scale those services— But what about monitoring? Rollouts? Security policies? Adding a service mesh can help you tackle this set of challenges. In this talk, we'll learn how Istio, an open-source service mesh tool, lets you automate, monitor, and secure traffic for your services, without any changes to your application code. Through demos, we'll explore how Istio works, then incrementally add Istio configuration to our cluster for telemetry, traffic encryption, and network policies. You'll leave this talk understanding what a service mesh is for, and which subset of Istio features might work for you.

BIO: Megan O'Keefe is a Developer Relations Engineer at Google Cloud, where she helps users adopt microservices and service mesh technologies. Previously a Software Engineer at Cisco, Megan spent two years working on multi-cluster Kubernetes for edge computing. Today, Megan helps build tools and demos like istiobyexample.dev, and has spoken about Kubernetes at the Grace Hopper Celebration, KubeCon, and Google Cloud NEXT. She is interested in DevOps, Go, and open source.

[08:00 - 08:30 PM] Stick around, socialize & network!

name: What is accessibility and why do you need to think about it?
description:
According to the CDC, roughly 25% of US adults have a disability. Many people with disabilities will interact with a website and consume its content in different ways and sometimes with different devices or assistive technologies, like screen readers. Therefore, a website needs to be built in a way that meets the needs of people with a variety of disabilities, including vision, hearing, mobility, cognitive, and others.

For a website to be accessible, content and interfaces must be perceivable, operable, understandable, and robust. The Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) are centered on those four principles.

Elianna James is an Accessibility SME for CVS Health. She works with design (UX and UI) and developers, business owners and other members of software development teams. Her role is to ensure that new website updates and features are created in ways that ensure they are accessible for everyone.

For our meeting she will explain who we are designing for and how we can get there without compromising our creativity. We'll talk about color contrast, alt text for logos and images, how to imagine your designs being accessed by keyboard-only methods as well as how you can test your assumptions and your designs while they are still wireframes.

Bring your questions. Send us a url in advance and we'll do a little accessibility/ design group investigation at the meeting.

We will have pizza at 5:45 pm (Ron will pick up early so it's there on time)!

description:

<p>Aaron Lieberman, a MuleSoft Practice Manager and Lead Consultant at Big Compass will walk us through on how Runtime Fabric can deploy and manage applications deployed to AWS. He will also demonstrate on how a Mule 3 and Mule 4 application can run in parallel in the same Runtime Fabric. With any public API, it has never been more important to enhance your security posture and provide deep visibility with logging and monitoring techniques. Aaron will also talk about how security and logging can work seamlessly with your distributed application network to make supporting any application better.</p><p>Finally, any modern application must be highly available and provide fault tolerance. We will have some fun with wreaking havoc on our Runtime Fabric infrastructure, and see how the highly available architecture holds up against potential infrastructure outages and attacks.</p></p>

name: Intro To DevOps with Silvia, Anthony, and Aaron - 3rd run!
description:
[NOTES]:
Show up at 9AM or so for class prep if you haven't yet installed the prereqs, socialize, food, class begins proper at 10AM. Fresh baked goods and coffee will be provided all day, catered lunch provided as well!

Please go to EARLY SIGN-IN FORM below to officially reg for the class

$256 pay or PWYC*

[EARLY SIGN-IN FORM]:
https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSd3IsB5QPU4VApnIC4oBmQoaRrGPmVam6E3SkToC7qNK9l6_Q/viewform?usp=pp_url&entry.2103456709=Intro+to+DevOps+3&entry.7419140=2019-10-19

[COURSE DESCRIPTION]:

We'll use Linux, Bash, Git, Gitlab, F5/Nginx Docker image, and AWS to create minimum viable DevOps continuous integration pipelines on our laptops. This class is based on content created by Aaron Brown, systems engineer and VP of DevOps at Flowhub.com.

Linux/Bash basics - the tildae, paths, tab completion, command history, variables, command substitution

Git and Gitlab - ssh keys / authentication, GitLab API, local git directory, git commands, git clone, working with repos, continuous integration features

Docker - terms, test, Dockerfile, Docker build, Docker run, make webserver w/ Docker

AWS cloud infrastructure on free tier - authentication, Elastic IP, Cloud Formation, EC2

[PREREQUISITES]:

- Willingness to get up on Saturday morning, leave your home, and take a class all day with friendly dedicated people you may not know well, or at all...

... and these: https://gitlab.com/sofreeus/introtodevops#prerequisites

[MORE INFO]: https://gitlab.com/sofreeus/introtodevops

[Q&A]:

Q: Who is this class for?

A: LEARNERS who are one or more of the following (no particular order):

- MID-CAREER IT PROS - update skill set, fill gaps, continuous learning

- TEACHERS OF IT OR ASPIRING - regardless of IT skill level, your interest is in the idea of teaching as a way of learning, networking with the like-minded

- DEVELOPERS - want or need to understand the IT infrastructure part of the equation better for career development

- CURIOUS - would like a gentle hands-on intro to determine if this is a good career path... don't want to rely solely on google or other online tutorials to figure that out

- TEAM MANAGERS - take or send someone to the class - even if not on the keyboard as much, this will be beneficial

[NOTES]: a little experience with linux basics prior to class helps but is not necessary

employers will often pay for this kind of learning if asked

[THE TEACHERS]:

name: Chris Maki: Serverless Computing
description:
5:30-6:00: Food, Soda, Beer, and Networking

6:00-6:15: Announcements

6:15-7:45: Serverless Computing

When you think of Serverless, you probably think of Lambda or Cloud Functions - but there's so much more to the Serverless ecosystem. We will look at Serverless Computing in all its various forms, and discuss why you might want to use a Serverless architecture and how it compares to other cloud services.

We'll look at a couple of popular frameworks, build a local Serverless function, and deploy it to AWS (if the network cooperates). Finally, we'll talk about performance considerations and how to structure your Serverless functions.

About Chris Maki

Chris Maki is the founder and Chief Architect of Rip City Software, a company dedicated to Java Microservices and building systems in AWS. He has more than 20 years of experience creating web-scale enterprise systems. Throughout his career, Chris has been a user group leader, speaker, and author. He's passionate about inclusive leadership, empowering teams, focusing on differentiated work and streamlining the development, testing, and deployment process.

You can find Chris on Twitter @cmaki (https://twitter.com/cmaki).

7:45: Door prizes

name: Five Star Software Architecture Workshop w/Mark Richards
description:
Super Early Bird Registration: $2,500/person thru 8/30
JUG Discount: $250, use the code archjug250 when registering
Special Offer: Register 3 and get the 4th registration free!

https://nofluffjuststuff.com/n/training/2019/10/21/software_architecture_training

This intensive hands-on training course is designed to provide you with the knowledge, skills, and roadmap necessary to become an effective software architect. Being a software architect is much more than just drawing boxes and lines. It's about thinking like an architect, being a leader, and understanding the architectural elements, patterns, and styles necessary to create effective software architectures. Through interactive course materials and architecture exercises, this course will teach you both the technical aspects of software architecture as well as the soft skills of architecture.

Knowing what architecture pattern best fit your situation is critical to the success of your architecture. In this course you will gain an in-depth understanding of many different architecture styles and patterns, including event-driven, microkernel, space-based, microservices, and service-based architectures. You will learn how each pattern works, the major characteristics of each pattern, and how to use each architecture style to create an effective software architecture that matches your business needs and requirements.

From an architecture soft skills perspective you will learn how important leadership, communication, facilitation, and negotiation skills are to a software architect, as well as some of the techniques for acquiring these skills. You will also learn many other soft skills techniques, such as how to think like an architect, make effective architecture decisions, and how to make development teams effective.

Whether you are on the path of developer to architect or already an architect, this course will provide you with the necessary practical hands-on real-world technical and soft-skills knowledge to quickly become an effective software architect.

name: The Progressive Web Experience
description:
Early Bird ends October 18th! Register today for the 2019 Progressive Web Experience & next level your Web Skills!

The 2019 Progressive Web Experience is THE event that brings together web developers and architects who are changing the face of the web. You will gain a deeper understanding of emerging technologies, fresh ideas, and best practices.

Mastering the mobile web using Progressive Web Apps (PWAs) and Progressive Enhancement techniques is a critical success factor. PWX 2019 is an unmatched opportunity to build your front-end development skills.

PWX 2019 will offer over 90 sessions/workshops on:

*PWAs, Angular, React, Vue.js, JavaScript, TypeScript,

name: Monthly Presentation Night
description:
Join us at our monthly gathering where we present topics of interest to Rubyists and aspiring programmers.

Doors open at 5:30pm, where you can hangout and socialize with other Boulder Ruby members. We have food and beverages available to add to the enjoyment.

At 6:30, we do announcements before getting to our presentations.

==================================
Talk 1: How we deliver software at Brandfolder by Brett Nekolny - Head of Engineering @ Brandfolder

Description: “Ship fast, sustainably” to us means delivering product rapidly to our customer base without burning out our team or our user’s patience with bugs and fires. We’ll go over the engineering practices that allow us to deploy 20+ times/day and high confidence in our product.

Bio: Brett has worked in a variety of languages: C++, C#, Python, Go, and Ruby and a variety of roles including automation and tooling, backend engineering, team lead, and management roles. He believes in enabling teams through individual empowerment and autonomy; this manifests through both culture and process but velocity with confidence is his guiding light.

==================================

Talk 2: Rails API performance and sparse fields by Logan Sears - Technical Product Manager & Sr. Software Engineer @ Brandfolder

Description: With the growth of our business, and the content people store in their Brandfolder we’ve seen an increasing need to make sure our API/platform are performant. We’ll go over a few specific efforts that have allowed us to scale our Rails API including leveraging sparse fields, and a deep dive into performance on our highest throughput endpoint.

Bio: Logan has spent much of his career becoming adept within the Ruby on Rails ecosystem and it’s surrounding tooling and methodologies. He enjoys creating thoughtful code that tries to achieve both maintainability and elegance. Most recently, he has directed his focus to impact the future of the product decisions at Brandfolder; he has significant perspective that allows him to collaborate with the team and come to product decisions while keeping in mind the technical implications.

==================================

If you would like to present at this meeting, or at upcoming events, reach out to the organizers on this meetup or ping us at @boulderruby (https://twitter.com/boulderruby) on Twitter.
how_to_find_us: Suite 115 - Recurly Offices

name: Type Parameters, Implicits, and Evidence
description:
Interested in learning more about Scala's type system and how it helps enable some of the "magic" in Spark's encoders? Want to enjoy free food and beverage while meeting fellow Scala engineers? If so, you'll want to attend the first Scala meetup at Strava Denver HQ.

For this kick-off event, Jack Kelly from FullContact will be presenting the following talk:

Type Parameters, Implicits, and Evidence: Ad-Hoc Polymorphism in SparkSQL's Encoders

This talk will include an introduction to type parameters and implicits in the Scala language, an explanation of how they can be combined into evidence for ad-hoc polymorphism via type classes, and an example of how ad-hoc polymorphism is used to supply encoders to SparkSQL's datasets.

Schedule:
6-6:30: Dinner and networking
6:30-7:30: Presentation and Q&A
7:30-8:00: Social time/wrap up.

Please RSVP so that we can get an accurate headcount for the food and beverages. All visitors to the office will need to sign in/sign an NDA on an iPad at the entrance before attending the event.
how_to_find_us: Enter in the front door of office at street level, take stairs or elevator to 3rd floor, look for wooden door for 310 to the left of the elevator/bathroom vestibule.

description:
Topic: Golang Birthday Party & Lightning Talks

We'll be celebrating Go's 10th Birthday a month early for our final Meetup of the year. In addition to the usual beer and pizza, we'll also have cake to celebrate!

A short talk on the history of Go will be provided by the organizers. In addition, we also have four slots available for Lightning Talks. If you're interested in filling one of these slots, please reach out to us here: http://bit.ly/MhgOct19Talks

A big thanks to our main sponsors for this event.
Pivotal Labs: Pizza & Space
Beer: TekSystems
Cake: Comcast

Food and beer will be available. We will also be live streaming the event to Twitch (https://bit.ly/2ORyzaK) and posting the talks to our YouTube page (https://bit.ly/2CXk94c). Make sure to subscribe!

GETTING THERE:

The meetup is located in LoHi, just northwest of Downtown, off Platte St. We are on the second floor above Brider. Just take the elevator up. (https://goo.gl/maps/x3FVhipBjUB2)

PARKING:

There is metered parking on Platte St. If that is full there is also four parking garages in the surrounding buildings.

Youtube https://www.youtube.com/milehighgophers
Slide Deck: https://bit.ly/mhgslides
Job openings: https://bit.ly/denvergojobs
Gophers Slack: https://gophers.slack.com/

description:

Adtaxi
Arrow Electronics
Beatport
Conga
Convercent
Greenhouse Software
Recurly

name: Coding and Project Night
description:
Project night!

(Reminder: If you're planning on coming, please RSVP! Having a record of who attends makes it easier for us to improve this meeting for you.)

With an established space come established rhythms, and one that everyone wants to see back is the time to really dig into projects. This is that time! Connect with project leads to organize and hack at project priorities. If you have a project that would benefit the brigade (easier reporting, easier time management), don't be afraid to hack at it using this time. Any credentials you need are freely available from an experienced brigade member.

name: New & Returning Members Night
description:
Details
New & Returning Members Night is where we welcome any new members to Code for Denver and where any returning members can continue working with their team on projects.

If you’re a new member, or curious about joining Code for Denver, there will be an onboarding session at this night that won't last the whole three hour meeting.

You can learn more about Code for Denver, including our open projects, at www.codefordenver.org.

FAQ
───
There is a full FAQ posted on our GitHub, but here are some highlights we think are important.

Where is Workability, and where do I park?
--------------------------------------------------
Workability is at 1576 Sherman St, Denver, CO 80203 in Denver.

Parking is street parking at meters, but all meters in the area are free starting at 6pm. There are also lots that are more expensive.

What do I need to bring to my first meetup?
--------------------------------------------------
We will have you create some accounts both on our site and for the technology we use, so a laptop or a smartphone will be useful.

I'm a beginner programmer. Can I still get involved?
--------------------------------------------------
Yes! Many of our members have been beginning programmers who have found the environment helpful to improve their abilities while also working on real world problems and providing value.

I'm not a programmer or interested in programming. Can I still get involved?
--------------------------------------------------
Yes! Helping solve challenges in the community takes more than programming expertise. Our brigade volunteers also have backgrounds in marketing, design, sales, facilitation, nonprofits, project management, and more. Additional perspectives and experiences are always valued and welcome.

What is Code for Denver current working on?
--------------------------------------------------
We have multiple teams working on many different projects at completely different stages. You can find the list, including general descriptions, status, skills needed, and more at our Current Projects page on the website.

Who can I contact for additional questions?
--------------------------------------------------
Get in touch with our organizers via our Meetup site or drop us a line at [masked]

name: Secure Your Future
description:
Strategies from the experts to protect yourself from hackers.

Join SecureSet and Denver Women in Tech for an in depth look at how you can protect yourself and your future from malicious hackers.

What are hackers after?
What do hackers do and how are you susceptible?
What can you do to protect yourself?
What if you want to help protect others?

This SecureSet Hacking 101 workshop is eligible for 2 hours of CPE credit! Ask a SecureSet staff member at the event if you would like to receive a CPE certificate.

Please register to ensure accurate planning for refreshments! https://secureset.com/event/secure-your-future-with-secureset-and-dwit-den-101019/

Bring a friend and snag some swag!

Meet the instructor:
Ajay Menendez is a 30 year Veteran of Information Technology whose areas of expertise are Cyber Security, Security (Intelligence, Analytics, Engineering), Technical Training, Course Development and Instruction, Enterprise Storage, Network (Engineering, Design,Optimization), Audio-Video and Information Technology Integration, Rich Media (Video Conferencing, IPTV, Digital Signage, Web-Conferencing, Web-casting), Unified Communications. He also holds a Bachelor’s degree in Applied Psychological Behavioral Analysis.

Agenda:
6:00-6:30 | Snacks, wine, and networking
6:30-8:00 | Presentation – Secure Your Future
8:00-8:30 | Q&A and wrap up

Everyone is welcome and invited to attend this event, regardless of gender.

What to bring:
+ Curiosity and questions if you have them
+ Laptop or pen/paper for taking notes
+ Business cards for networking

Parking:
There is a paid lot at the corner of 22nd and Blake. Meters are easily accessible for $1.00 per hour. If you go north of 23rd on Blake, Market or Welton, there is street parking for free and you can walk in.
how_to_find_us: secureset.com

name: October Develop Happy Hour
description:
Come hang out with fellow members of the growing Denver/Boulder tech scene. Everyone is welcome. Come to learn, make contacts or discuss your latest project. No speaker, no agenda, no code knowledge necessary, just drinks.

Monthly Happy Hour. We are always open to suggestions for new venues to host the happy hour. Please feel free to message the us with any ideas.
how_to_find_us: We'll be enjoying the views of Sloans Lake from the rooftop patio.

name: Halloween Costume Develop Happy Hour
description:
You asked for it and now you’re going to get it. Halloween Costume Happy Hour at our most requested venue, Casa Bonita! name: Downtown Denver Tech Interview Meetup
description:
Programmers, sharpen your skills or prepare for an interview. Discover what you don't know, that you don't know. Before you interview for real, practice with us.

Here's what to expect..

* Choose Your Own Interview - We have studied actual job descriptions to create a few mock job descriptions that generally fit the career path of most folks.

Entry Level Frontend Developer
Entry Level Backend Developer
Experienced Frontend Developer
Experienced Backend Developer

(see them at http://www.denvertechinterview.com/mock-jobs)

You'll choose the job description that most closely fits you, and your interview will be based on the details of that job description overall. You can select specific items if you'd like a grilling on that topic.

-- Whiteboard exercises.
Write working code without an IDE, or perhaps design a system from the top of your head. You'll need knowledge in a wide range of software engineering topics in order to answer these most efficiently, and to get the job.

-- Focus on the fundamentals.
Go in-depth on the foundational knowledge you need to answer whiteboard exercises. From data structures and algorithms to databases and language specifics.. From backend to browsers, these topics will make sure you've got the basics down pat.

You can do this all over, and over again, getting your mind right, before you go do the real thing.

Inspiring quote:
"We choose to do this, not because it is easy, but because it is hard." -- President John F. Kennedy (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ouRbkBAOGEw) (more or less)

Find out where you're strong, and help others where they are weak! The best way to learn, is to teach.

About our Sponsor:

Galvanize
Galvanize is a Learning Community for Technology. They offer anyone with the aptitude and ambition the tools to grow their career or startup. They do that through having membership for office space, education opportunities in both data science or web development (where they have both immersive programs and part-time classes), and enterprise solutions like custom employee training, off-site events, or event space for things like this meetup.

name: The Real Mock Interview - #1
description:
This time its for real!

Its still a mock interview, but we record this one, and make it available, so future employers can see.

To be the first of many, let's round out the year with the interview we've been practicing for.

Details to come.

name: Denver JavaScript Study Group: Hacktober Night 🎃
description:
Join us in WeWork The Hub (RiNo) for Denver JavaScript Study Group: Hacktober Night 🎃! This month we are doing something extra to celebrate open-source software! It's Hacktoberfest 2019! Anyone interested in learning about and/or contributing to open source is welcome. There will be will 2 chances to come work on open source with us this month, Oct 10th and Oct 24th. As a quick note, you can come and work on any open-source projects, Hacktober Night 🎃is not JavaScript specific.

🎃 What's Hacktoberfest?

Hacktoberfest — brought to you by DigitalOcean in partnership with DEV — is a month-long celebration of open-source software.
To qualify for the official limited edition Hacktoberfest shirt, you must register and make four pull requests between October 1-31. No contribution is too small — bug fixes and documentation updates are valid ways of participating. Find out more at https://hacktoberfest.digitalocean.com/

🎃 Event Schedule

Let's celebrate open source over food, learning, and great company!

5:30 PM - Doors open
5:45 PM - Welcome notes from WWCode Denver
5:50 PM - Intro to Hacktoberfest: the celebration, prizes, and instructions
6:00 PM - PR demonstration + hack time
7:30 PM - Close

🎃 About the Host

This event is hosted by the Flatiron School. Flatiron School Denver, is more than just a coding school. We bring together passionate instructors, uncompromising education, verified outcomes, and an inclusive student community to fuel an authentic and open tech sphere. Flatiron School’s comprehensive curriculum is built to ensure students land jobs as developers upon graduation or get your money back.

🎃 Event Code of Conduct

Please read our Code of Conduct: https://www.womenwhocode.com/codeofconduct

Please read the Hacktoberfest events Code of Conduct: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1gFKOhyUqMZzrZcbq8A_TpO5x9J9HK6agv70awCH8pyI/edit

Happy hacking!

Leave the github link in our comments

https://opensource.guide/how-to-contribute/

name: Data Visualization & Intro to Tableau
description:
***This is a paid workshop. To purchase tickets, visit https://generalassemb.ly/education/data-visualization-and-intro-to-tableau/denver/86129

Fascinated by data visualization but don't have any experience beyond charts in Excel or Powerpoint?

Data visualizations are a critical business tool. This class serves as an introduction to the visual techniques that are often employed when describing, analyzing, and communicating data in a business setting. We’ll start by explaining the role of data visualization in a business setting, and then dive into basic visual methodology. We will cover the basic principles of data visualization, look at how data viz can be used to convey a message, and walk through the process of creating complex, dynamic visualizations.

Come and learn the basics, and get the skills you need to own that next staff meeting, marketing presentation, or business pitch!

Takeaways:

- Describe the business value in visualizing data
- Identify different types of data visualizations and how to use them effectively
- Learn how to use Tableau to create different data visualizations

Preparation:

Please bring a laptop with Tableau Desktop (free) pre-installed Please download the data set for the workshop that will be sent out prior to class

name: Branding Workshop
description:
This is a paid event, please use this link to purchase a ticket https://generalassemb.ly/education/branding-workshop/denver/86576

About This Class
In today’s marketplace, brand is king. Regardless of the nature and size of your organization, it’s important to invest in building a strong brand to define your niche in the marketplace and help you stand out from the crowd.

By answering the most important questions about your brand, audience and competitive landscape, you can then build on this to drive product development, customer acquisition, employee engagement and strategic partnerships.

In this workshop we will talk through the creative & strategic elements of branding including:

The importance of branding
Intentional vs unintentional branding
Brand concept vs. brand identity
Creating and audience persona
How to tell a brand story
Competitors & differentiation
Visual design, tone words, color
Choosing iconography, photography & visual elements
This workshop will cover how to develop a strong brand using the strategies above, with a particular focus on how to build a powerful and impressive online presence.

Preparation
Please come to the workshops with a laptop or notebook/pen. Students will gain the most from this workshop if they have a business or brand they are actively developing and can prepare themselves by thinking about the unique needs of the target audience, the baseline for this product or service to succeed in the marketplace and their own passion for the business vision. The principles learned can be applied to personal branding; however, this will not be the focus of the session.

name: Monthly DenverScript Meetup
description:
6:15 pm: Intro and What's going on in JavaScript Land? (20min)

We'll be talking about new/exciting things going on in the industry. If you have something you think we should mention, feel free to tweet us @DenverScript (https://twitter.com/denverscript).

6:35 pm: Job Announcements

Anyone with a job opening can come up to the front and announce it to the group.

6:45 pm: Shorter Presentation(8 - 10min):

Decoupling Child from Parent - Phil Lucks

Should a parent component care about when a child component renders, or should the child own itself and tell the parent to MYOB? This topic will cover the pros & cons of coupled components and why you may choose one over the other. Ideally, the audience will participate too so everyone can learn from the experiences of others.

Phil has been working as a Front-End Engineer for over 3 years. If I'm lucky I remember the code I wrote from 1 week ago.

7:00 pm: Longer Presentation(20 - 30min):

Brief Intro to SvelteJS - Courtney Fay

What is Svelte? What makes it different than other frameworks out there? How does it work under the hood? (I'll try to make any JS connections possible) Why is everyone so psyched about it? Is it really the next big thing? How can I get started on my first Svelte project?

Court graduated from General Assembly's web dev program in Dec 2016. She spent 2017 helping make bank websites at IHS Markit, and just started her second dev job at a startup that she thinks has the potential to reduce the cost of healthcare in America.

Socialize:

We'll have beer and pizza! We'll also allow people to announce any job opportunities they may have at that time so you can socialize with potential applicants.

name: FCIP October Meetup: State Management in Flutter Applications
description:
The architecture of an application usually determines how maintainable, extensible and testable it is. The question is: How does this work in Flutter apps where everything, and we mean everything, is a widget?

Join us on Tuesday, October 15, as Dean Iverson takes an in-depth look at the four most popular solutions for state management in the Flutter community. He will start with an "Introduction to Flutter" talk emphasizing state management/architecture and discuss the pros and cons of each as well as how we can effectively separate our application's logic from its UI so we don't end up with an untestable pile of spaghetti. By the end, you'll have the information you need to be able to choose the solution that's right for your project.

Complimentary drinks and appetizers will be served at 5:45pm. The presentation will start at 6:00pm with Q&A to follow. RSVP today!

MORE ABOUT OUR SPEAKER:
Dean Iverson is the client applications lead in the Center for Technology Implementation at the Virginia Tech Transportation Institute. CTI's focus is to help clients bridge the gap between pure R&D and the initial deployment of new technologies in the real world. These days, most of CTI's work involves writing software to support research on connected and autonomous vehicle technologies.

Image credit: https://levelup.gitconnected.com/flutter-to-build-ios-android-apps-f8786d6fe987

name: FCIP December Meetup: The Importance of Visual Design
description:
Contrary to the old adage, people do judge a book by its cover. What we see influences not only how we feel about something but also how much we trust it.

The visual appearance of your work is judged every time it's shared, and how it looks impacts the recipient's perception of the information and of you (whether they intended it to or not).

Join us on Tuesday, December 3, as Luciano Vizza discusses the UX and business value of good visual design, unpacks some tried and true principles, and then applies those principles to the redesign of a site page.

If you'd like to get a sneak peek at some of the design principles he'll discuss, check out Luciano's Medium post: https://medium.com/otlventures/yes-i-think-your-document-is-ugly-f37d2da0e699

Complimentary drinks and appetizers will be served at 5:45pm. The presentation will start at 6:00pm with Q&A to follow. RSVP today!

MORE ABOUT OUR SPEAKER:
Luciano Vizza is a co-founder & product designer at OTL Ventures. He's a self-taught product designer who happened upon product design while starting a company in college. Ever since then, he's been fascinated with how successful businesses at their core have a well-crafted product, delivering value to their customers. He loves talking about good UX, eating good food, and drinking a finely crafted cup of coffee. Learn more about OTL Ventures at: http://www.otlventures.com/

Image credit: https://digitalsynopsis.com/design/visual-hierarchy-graphic-design-principles/

name: HTML + CSS Foundations
description:
Register on Eventbrite: http://bit.ly/htmlCSS-bd

Whether you’re brand new to coding or preparing for admission into a software engineering immersive, our Learn to Code series is designed for you to learn the basics of HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. Our instructors are carefully selected to give the best experience possible in a fun, hands-on learning environment. Instructors provide a thoughtful blend of lectures, code-alongs, and study hall sessions.

So, where should you start?

If you are just beginning your learning journey as a developer, we recommend beginning with our HTML + CSS Foundations workshop followed by JavaScript 101 and JavaScript 201, or our JavaScript Bootcamp for Beginners, which covers JavaScript 101 and 201 all in one day.

Know the basics? Jump into our JavaScript offerings, or reach out to our Enrollment Officer, Alison, at [masked] to create your own learning plan. 

In addition, be sure to explore our online prep options! We recommend Premium Prep - check it out: http://bit.ly/bd-seiPrep

About this workshop:

During this beginner workshop you will learn the essentials of HTML and CSS while gaining a basic understanding of how the web works. Once we’ve covered the basics, you will be guided through the construction of your very own website followed by an optional study hall session.

What You'll Learn:

-Basic Web Architecture
-Foundations of HTML
-Foundations of CSS
-“Learn to Learn” Methodology
-Text Editors
-How to build a web page

What to bring:

Students will need to bring their own laptops and charger. Windows, Mac or Linux will do it!

About Galvanize:

Galvanize is the premier dynamic learning community for technology. With campuses located in booming technology sectors throughout the country, Galvanize provides a community for each the following:

Education – part-time and full-time training in software engineering, data science, and data engineering

Workspace – whether you’re a freelancer, startup, or established business, we provide beautiful spaces with a community dedicated to supporting your company’s growth

Networking – events in the tech industry happen constantly in our campuses, ranging from popular Meetups to multi-day international conferences

To learn more about the Software Engineering Immersive at Galvanize, visit https://www.galvanize.com/web-development

If you have specific questions regarding our Software Engineering Immersive, or want to speak with our Enrollment Officer, please reach out to [masked] or book a time here: alisonsipos.youcanbook.me

name: Meet NestJS with Ely Lucas - Node.js Denver/Boulder/Ft. Collins
description:
Talk:

Meet NestJS with Ely Lucas

Nest is a server-side framework for Node, that uses modern language features (via TypeScript) to create efficient, reliable, and scalable apps. The popularity of Nest has been exploding lately as developers are discovering how easy and powerful it is to build server-side applications with it. Front end developers are finding it especially easy to dive into full-stack development with Nest, while backend developers from other frameworks are finding familiar features they expect from a top-class web framework. In this talk, we will get introduced to Nest and discover how to create a simple, yet functional, API with it.

---

Speaker:

Ely Lucas
@elylucas

Ely is a web and mobile developer living in Denver, CO with his wife, four kids, and dog. He works at Ionic as a software engineer and developer advocate and loves all things web. When not coding, he enjoys learning new tech and sharing with others.

---

Schedule:

6:30pm: Pizza, beer, networking
7:00pm: Talk
7:45pm: Questions

Hope you all can make it out to this great talk. If you have any questions, don't hesitate to reach out.

name: Intro to JavaScript: A Free Coding Class at The Tech Academy
description:
We run a code school. We hear from a lot of people we talk to that they're not sure whether they're interested in a job in the tech field, because they don't know enough about it. Sometimes, they've even been told that "programming is hard to learn."

At The Tech Academy, we work hard to break down the barriers between people and technology. We think that, with the right approach, anyone can learn to code - and whether you end up working in technology or not, the principles behind coding are useful in a lot of areas.

The Tech Academy is offering a free course on Introduction to JavaScript. JavaScript is universally recognized as a foundational language. It is present in every platform imaginable: like browsers, mobile, and desktop applications.

This course is perfect for people with little to no experience in programming who are curious about a career in software development.

In this practical, hands-on class, you'll learn the basics of these popular technologies - and along the way, you should find out for yourself whether technology and coding are something worth looking into a bit more deeply.

Please Note:
---Make sure to bring your laptop, as this will be a hands on learning process where you get to actually write your own code. If you don't have a laptop, no worries, you will be able to use one of ours.
---An RSVP is needed to guarantee a seat in the class, though we may have a few open seats for last minute attendees.
---You must be at least 18 years of age to attend this class.
how_to_find_us: We are located on the first floor of the building complex under the dental offices.
